description: From Middle English capoun; partly from Old Northern French capon (Old French chapon) and partly from Old English capūn, both from Latin capo, caponem (Vulgar Latin *cappo), from Proto-Indo-European *kop- (“to strike, to beat”).

entries.meaning: A cockerel which has been gelded and fattened for the table.

verbs.description: capon (third-person singular simple present capons, present participle caponing, simple past and past participle caponed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To castrate; to make a capon of.
